comment_text:
I've heard a couple/few YouTubers say they're thinking about getting the 'Pro' version of the HD1, but I haven't heard anyone say *why* they want the Pro over the less expensove 'Essential' or the more expensive 'Ultra'. Would you be willing to make a video talking about the peos and cons of each unit, as you see them?

I "backed" them and opted for the Ultra. I didn't just do it because "higher number = better" but because the Ultra has the MOPA fiber laser, and that's something I *think* I want...

I mean, I like having more settings to play with and I think the colors that can be put onto stainless steel and titanium look pretty cool, both things that having MOPA enables, but I haven't used either type of fiber laser so maybe I'd change my mind if I had more information... For instance, if the colors aren't *that* great in real life, maybe the extra cost won't be as valuable to me any longer.

video_title: $300 Ink?! The REAL Cost of the EufyMake UV Printer
comment_text: Parts supply has been pretty terrible for ankermake printers for years. They do have some parts but it's very normal for them to go out of stock for months with 0 way to backorder. Anker also abandoned their slicer software and mobile app years ago. It was left in a pretty buggy state. They have also outsourced a lot of their support to members of their discord community and have almost no official interaction with customers there. Community members have had to build custom print profiles for orca because the default profiles were extremely poor and resulted in repeated print failures. There also have been multiple reports of customers returning defective printers under warranty and being sent back a barely functional refurbished unit with major problems. I am confident this product works well and based on what I see there's nothing else on the market similarly priced. Just keep in mind anker support is awful and they do not have any loyalty to you as a customer. They will abandon you the second this product appears to be a commercial failure.

video_title: $300 Ink?! The REAL Cost of the EufyMake UV Printer
comment_text: $300 ink is nothing. First of all, it prints in almost anything. Comes with the cylinder option, and on top of that, it does things no other printer can do.  My first color laser printer that ONLY printed flat images in paper and didn’t print photos very well at all, cost over 400 bucks for a set of toner, and then you had to buy a 150 dollar drum as well. So complaining about ink for this is like ….dumb. Esp when you cal sell individual pieces for seriously marked up cost.

video_title: Is THIS the Future of Printing?  - eufyMake E1 UV Printer
comment_text: I have concerns regarding consumables the fact the machine can never be shut off without flushing the lines without knowing how much ink is lost and how many times you can flush the lines before the cleaner kit needs to be replaced. and also the machine does a cleaning cycle when not in use every few hours again not knowing ink loses and clean kit life. these are extremely expensive ink cartridges so losing ink so often to maintenance is worrisome let alone only a 3 month warranty on print heads which are extremely expensive. I was super excited and ready to jump in head first but after hearing about the ink lose and other consumables I'm struggling to see the value now, at least not without some more information on ink loss..

video_title: EVERYTHING About Lasers Will Change
comment_text:
Working with cutting lasers about 10 years ago for glass. We used mirrors to transmit the beam, with a focus setup on the head to adjust the final focus point and to compensate for the fluctuating movement.

Other setups used a scan head, 2 mirrors that would adjust x,y, with another focal lens to adjust for z as x,y changed the z distance changed from the point of emittance.

The distance was a few feet from the working surface.

comment_text:
Hi! I'm considering buying the sculpfun s70 max, has anyone already bought it and can share their opinion?
More in general, what do you think about sculpfun brand? In terms of construction and quality of the machines, any customer service, general experience?
I work with wood, acrylic and other materials suitable for a diode laser. For several years I have been using both co2 and diode engravers (not mine), and I decided to get a machine for myself. The most important thing is to have a large work area, for this reason my choice went to the s70 max (the alternative would be Atomstack A70 max, same characteristics but I read several negative opinions on after-sales assistance) thank you

video_title: Is THIS the Future of Printing?  - eufyMake E1 UV Printer
comment_text:
Being in school photography since 2016, I have lots of experience with printers. And the of the biggest issues are with the print head and ink.

- Ink tends to dry out and clog. Any news on how thos is handled with the resin? I known it's UV resin and doesn't exactly dry out. But over time, it can still happen. Colored resin isn't just resin. There's still ink particles that can clump up when sitting idle.

- The print head is easily the most annoying component. They shift and rare out over time. They're not easy nor cheap to replace. And it's not like we can just call a repair shop to come over and fix this one.

- I've ran into far too many issues with the ink spilling all over the printhead and down onto the paper and internal components. How would that be addressed with this printer? Resin would be a lot more difficult to remove than traditional liquid or powder ink.

- To add to that, how easy is it to repair/place the print bed components? The belt, the gears, etc?

video_title: EVERYTHING About Lasers Will Change
comment_text: If my limited knowledge about lasers is correct, the lower the wattage the smaller the laser point and the better for small engraving. I saw the demo on the 3D example and the steps. My question is this. With higher wattages on the Accalaser, will it be able to do smaller and more precise engraving? I'm wondering if the higher wattage are adjustable to your needs. I know power and speed go together, but you also want a precise and fine laser point when engraving smaller items. Just a point of view.

video_title: $300 Ink?! The REAL Cost of the EufyMake UV Printer
comment_text: I'm about ready to buy this, but if I heard this right. If the printer sits unused for more than 72 hours a deep cleaning cycle must be used. Meaning, you must constantly be banging out prints or you eat up cleaning cartridges for simply sitting idle. I'm on edge about buying this machine because everyone talking good about it got it for free sponsored, and isn't exactly giving a truly bias opinion. Eufymake also dumped on their customers in the past launching products then killing support and dropping the product line all together. The only hope I have is that adam savage from tested used this so I'd hope it would mean it would be continuously used. If the self cleaning cartridges were cheap then not much of an issue. If some other china company sells cheaper inks, great, many headaches cost wise solved.
